playn.core
Interface Layer

All Known Subinterfaces:
CanvasLayer, GroupLayer, ImageLayer, ImmediateLayer, ImmediateLayer.Clipped, Layer.HasSize, SurfaceLayer
All Known Implementing Classes:
AbstractLayer, CanvasLayerGL, GroupLayerGL, ImageLayerGL, ImmediateLayerGL, ImmediateLayerGL.Clipped, LayerGL, SurfaceLayerGL
public interface Layer

Layer is the base element for all rendering in PlayN

Each layer has a transformation matrix transform() and several other associated properties which can be manipulated directly (changes take effect automatically on the next rendered frame).

The root of the layer hierarchy is the rootLayer . All coordinates in a layer are transformed by the layer's transformation matrix, and each child layer is positioned by the transformation matrix of it's parent.

TODO: clipping (?), transform-origin: allow explicit "center, top-left, bottom-right" like CSS transform-origin?

Method Detail

destroy

void destroy()
Destroys this layer, removing it from its parent layer. Any resources associated with this layer are freed, and it cannot be reused after being destroyed. Destroying a layer that has children will destroy them as well.

destroyed

boolean destroyed()
Whether this layer has been destroyed. If true, the layer can no longer be used.

parent

GroupLayer parent()
Returns the parent that contains this layer, or null.

transform

pythagoras.f.Transform transform()
Returns the layer's transformation matrix.

visible

boolean visible()
Returns true if this layer is visible (i.e. it is being rendered).

setVisible

void setVisible(boolean visible)
Configures this layer's visibility: if true, it will be rendered as normal, if false it and its children will not be rendered.

interactive

boolean interactive()
Returns true if this layer reacts to clicks and touches. If a layer is interactive, it will respond to hitTest(pythagoras.f.Point), which forms the basis for the click and touch processing provided by Pointer#addListener, Touch#addListener and Mouse#addListener.

setInteractive

void setInteractive(boolean interactive)
Configures this layer as reactive to clicks and touches, or not. Note that a layer's interactivity is automatically activated when a listener is added to the layer (or to a child of a GroupLayer) via Pointer#addListener, etc. Also a GroupLayer will be made non-interactive automatically if an event is dispatched to it and it discovers that it has no interactive children. Manual management of interactivity is thus generally only useful for "leaf" nodes in the scene graph.

alpha

float alpha()
Return the global alpha value for this layer.

The global alpha value for a layer controls the opacity of the layer but does not affect the current drawing operation. I.e., when Game.paint(float) is called and the Layer is drawn, this alpha value is applied to the alpha channel of the Layer.

By default, the alpha for a Layer is 1.0 (not transparent).

Returns:
alpha in range [0,1] where 0 is transparent and 1 is opaque

setAlpha

void setAlpha(float alpha)
Set the global alpha value for this layer.

The global alpha value for a layer controls the opacity of the layer but does not affect the current drawing operation. I.e., when Game.paint(float) is called and the Layer is drawn, this alpha value is applied to the alpha channel of the Layer.

Values outside the range [0,1] will be clamped to the range [0,1].

Parameters:
alpha - alpha value in range [0,1] where 0 is transparent and 1 is opaque

originX

float originX()
Returns the x-component of the layer's origin.

originY

float originY()
Returns the y-component of the layer's origin.

setOrigin

void setOrigin(float x,
               float y)
Sets the origin of the layer.

This sets the origin of the layer's transformation matrix.

Parameters:
x - origin on x axis
y - origin on y axis

depth

float depth()
Sets the depth of this layer. Within a single GroupLayer, layers are rendered from lowest depth to highest depth.

setDepth

void setDepth(float depth)
Updates this layer's depth.

setTranslation

void setTranslation(float x,
                    float y)
Sets the translation of the layer.

This sets the translation of the layer's transformation matrix so coordinates in the layer will be translated by this amount.

Parameters:
x - translation on x axis
y - translation on y axis

setScale

void setScale(float x)
Sets the scale of the layer.

This sets the scale of the layer's transformation matrix so coordinates in the layer will be multiplied by this scale.

Note that a scale of 1 is equivalent to no scale.

Parameters:
x - non-zero scale value

setScale

void setScale(float x,
              float y)
Sets the scale of the layer.

This sets the scale of the layer's transformation matrix so coordinates in the layer will be multiplied by this scale.

Note that a scale of 1 is equivalent to no scale.

Parameters:
x - non-zero scale value on the x axis
y - non-zero scale value on the y axis

setRotation

void setRotation(float angle)
Sets the rotation of the layer.

This sets the rotation of the layer's transformation matrix so coordinates in the layer will be rotated by this angle.

Parameters:
angle - angle to rotate, in radians

hitTest

Layer hitTest(pythagoras.f.Point p)
Tests whether the supplied (layer relative) point "hits" this layer or any of its children. By default a hit is any point that falls in a layer's bounding box. A group layer checks its children for hits.

Note that this method mutates the supplied point. If a layer is hit, the point will contain the original point as translated into that layer's coordinate system. If no layer is hit, the point will be changed to an undefined value.

Returns:
this layer if it was the hit layer, a child of this layer if a child of this layer was hit, or null if neither this layer, nor its children were hit.

hitTestDefault

Layer hitTestDefault(pythagoras.f.Point p)
Like hitTest(pythagoras.f.Point) except that it ignores a configured Layer.HitTester. This allows one to configure a hit tester which checks custom properties and then falls back on the default hit testing implementation.

setHitTester

void setHitTester(Layer.HitTester tester)
Configures a custom hit tester for this layer. May also be called with null to clear out any custom hit tester.

addListener

Connection addListener(Pointer.Listener listener)
Registers a listener with this layer that will be notified if a click/touch event happens within its bounds. Events dispatched to this listener will have their Event#localX and Event#localY values set to the coordinates of the click/touch as transformed into this layer's coordinate system. Event#x and Event#y will always contain the screen (global) coordinates of the click/touch.

When a listener is added, the layer and all of its parents are marked as interactive. Interactive layers intercept touches/clicks. When all listeners are disconnected (including Mouse and Touch listeners), the layer will be marked non-interactive. Its parents are lazily marked non-interactive as it is discovered that they have no interactive children. Thus if you require that a layer continue to intercept click/touch events to prevent them from being dispatched to layers "below" it, you must register a NOOP listener on the layer, or manually call setInteractive(boolean) after removing the last listener.

addListener

Connection addListener(Mouse.Listener listener)
Registers a listener with this layer that will be notified if a mouse event happens within its bounds. Events dispatched to this listener will have their Event#localX and Event#localY values set to the coordinates of the mouse as transformed into this layer's coordinate system. Event#x and Event#y will always contain the screen (global) coordinates of the mouse.

Note that mouse wheel events are not dispatched, as they lack coordinates. If a game wishes to determine the layer over which the mouse is hovering when wheel events are dispatched, it can register a global mouse-movement handler to track the position of the mouse, and use the latest position to determine which layer is under the mouse at the time of wheeling.

When a listener is added, the layer and all of its parents are marked as interactive. Interactive layers intercept mice events. When all listeners are disconnected (including Pointer and Touch listeners), the layer will be marked non-interactive. Its parents are lazily marked non-interactive as it is discovered that they have no interactive children. Thus if you require that a layer continue to intercept mouse events to prevent them from being dispatched to layers "below" it, you must register a NOOP listener on the layer, or manually call setInteractive(boolean) after removing the last listener.
